title: 111_hr4390
content: The Act is titled the "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009." It introduces enhanced program and provider protections in the Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. The Secretary may impose enhanced oversight measures if there is a significant risk of fraudulent activity with providers or suppliers under title XVIII, XIX, or XXI. The Secretary can impose requirements on providers or suppliers under title XVIII, XIX, or XXI, including screening, enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations of authorizations. States may also be required to implement these provisions for title XIX and XXI. The Secretary can impose requirements on providers or suppliers under title XVIII, XIX, or XXI, including screening, enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations of authorizations. States may also be required to implement these provisions for title XIX and XXI. Screening procedures include licensing board checks, screening against exclusion lists, the excluded provider list system, and background checks. Actions and determinations made under these provisions are not subject to judicial review. The Secretary can impose requirements on providers or suppliers under titles XVIII, XIX, or XXI, including screening, enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations of authorizations. This includes background checks, unannounced site visits, and heightened disclosure of affiliations. Enhanced oversight procedures may include required or unannounced site visits, prepayment review, enhanced claims review, and other specified actions for a period of 30 to 365 days. The Secretary can extend oversight periods for providers or suppliers if necessary, including withholding payment for durable medical equipment from high-risk suppliers. The Secretary can establish a program for periodic review of physician authorizations to address excessive prescribing or authorization of items or services. Physicians or professionals will receive a quarterly list of claims submitted under the program for validation within a 90-day period. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on provider enrollment if serious fraud risk is found in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs. Providers must validate claims within 90 days to avoid denial of future claims. The Secretary can impose a moratorium on provider enrollment in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs if fraud risk is identified. States can conduct additional provider screening activities. A probationary period is established for new providers to determine legitimacy. During XVIII, XIX, or XXI, a probationary period of heightened review (up to 1 year) is imposed by the Secretary to validate claims and physician prescriptions. If a significant number of claims are deemed illegitimate, participation may be suspended or terminated. The Secretary may suspend or terminate a provider or supplier's participation with notice. Failure to cooperate in validating prescriptions may result in a civil monetary penalty of up to $10,000. Civil money penalties will be imposed in accordance with section 1128A. The provisions apply to penalties or proceedings under section 1128A(a). Prompt pay provisions are revised for contracts involving suspicious or fraudulent claim submissions. Conforming amendments are made to the Medicaid section of the Social Security Act. The curr_chunk revises provisions related to enforcement of determinations made by the Secretary under subsection (a) or (b) of section 1128G, ensuring enforcement of significant risk of fraudulent activity with providers or suppliers. The curr_chunk amends Section 2102 of the Act to include procedures for States to enforce Secretary's determinations regarding fraudulent activity and carry out required activities for program integrity. The curr_chunk amends Medicare regulations to enhance program integrity by applying provisions of section 1128G to enrollments of providers and suppliers. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with the Inspector General when identifying significant risks of fraudulent activity. The curr_chunk authorizes additional funding for the implementation of the amendments made to enhance program integrity in Medicare regulations. The effective date for these amendments is upon the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will implement regulations under section 1128G(b) of the Social Security Act for providers and suppliers approved after 6 months from the enactment of the Act. The regulations will be effective immediately on an interim basis, with a period for public comments before any revisions can be made.
